title: Why is The White Album a double album? - Quora

response.answer_text: A combination of too many songs for one album and an unwillingness to edit them down is the reason it became a double album. Lennon, McCartney and Harrison found not much spirituality but a lot of inspiration in India with the Maharishi. They came back with armloads of new songs. They had enough clout to record and release whatever they wished, and a double album was just what they wanted, a rock-star move if there ever was one. It was also the beginning of the end for the band’s cohesiveness. Before the trip to India they had recorded a few songs to tide over the market while they were gone. Lady Madonna and Hey Bulldog were both put in the can in these sessions. The production staff later said that this was the last time the Beatles really worked together as a band in the studio. The give and take collaboration and joy they found in making music together was still there. It was also the first time Lennon brought Yoko into the studio, much to the others’ annoyance. The White Album was a symptom of the growing independence of the members. Lennon and McCartney weren’t collaborating much anymore, just presenting their already finished songs for the other to critique. Harrison was increasingly frustrated by the lack of access his songs had. McCartney was becoming insistent about how his songs were played, which ticked off everyone. Lennon’s drug habit included heroin by then. Even Ringo walked away at one point when his drumming was criticized. Despite all of this, maybe because of it, the album turned out gloriously disjointed, with wild changes of mood and downright weirdness that doesn’t exist on any other Beatles album. I think it’s fantastic.

Why indeed. The short answer is that the Beatles were, at that point, powerful enough to release whatever the hell they wanted to release, and neither their producer nor their label had the power to stop them. By this point in their career, they’d ceased to function as a regular unit, which is why you get silly songs like ‘Bungalow Bill’ and ‘Rocky Raccoon’ and Ringo’s forgettable ‘Don’t Pass Me By’ alongside casual masterpieces like ‘Long Long Long’ and ‘Happiness is a Warm Gun’. I think it’s notable that nearly all the best tracks on the White Album came about when they were able to work together: ‘Happiness is a Warm Gun’ is, in my view, one of the best things they ever did, and it was recorded live in one take; they didn’t record the different parts separately and edit them together. That took serious teamwork. But, they spent a lot of the rest of the time in a huff, working on their own or with one other member, and so there’s a lot of material that would not normally have passed quality control. I am, however, one of the few people who would not want to be without ‘Revolution Nine’, which for its sheer perversity I think is another of the best things they ever did. The Word of God (and his helper) answers, transcribed from the Beatles’ Anthology documentary, are: George Martin: When they did the White Album…I thought we should have made a very, very good single album out of it, rather than making a double album. Ringo Starr: Well, no, I agree, we should have put it out as two separate albums. The White and the Whiter Album. George Harrison: But, you know…what do you do when you’ve got all them songs, and you wanna get rid of them so you can do, you know, more songs? You know, there was a lot of, uh, you know, ego in that band, and there was a lot of songs that should have just maybe been elbowed or made into B-sides. Paul McCartney: Well, you can always say that, I mean…say, perhaps…I’ll go with…not definitely. I mean, in fact, I think it’s a fine little album. I think that the fact that it’s got so much on it is one of the things that’s cool about it. Cause they’re very varied stuff, you know, ‘Rocky’, ‘Piggies’…’Happiness is a Warm Gun’, that kind of stuff. I think it’s a fine album. [pause, smirks] You know, I’m not a great one for that, ‘Maybe it’s too many of that’, look, what do you mean, it was great, it sold, it’s the bloody Beatles’ White Album! Shut up! Edit: For what it’s worth, my own opinion is that it’s no use wishing history had gone differently.
